msContents.summary: The Pañcarakṣā corpus ("Five Protections") consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit colleIction, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. This manuscript is an old palm-leaf exemplar of the corpus, probably to be dated to the 13th-14th century. The order of the single texts is different from the one in the other manuscripts in the Cambridge collections. The manuscript is illustrated with depictions of the five Śaktis, one at the beginning of each chapter. Both covers are decorated, each with three Buddhas and six smaller, attending figures.

msItem.title: Pañcarakṣā
msItem.incipit: [1v1] evam mayā śrutam e:%kasmin sama[miniature]ye bhagavān rā%jagṛhe viharati sma ||
msItem.finalRubric: [97v3] || @ || āryamahāśītavatī daṇḍadhāra%ṇī nāma % vidyārajñī parisamāptaḥ || @ || % ye dharmā gāthetyādi || @ || @ ||

supportDesc.extent: 133 ff. (including one unnumbered flyleaf at the beginning).
supportDesc.foliation: Nepalākṣarā numerals, top right string hole space, verso (101-123).
supportDesc.condition: Complete, generally in good condition. Sometimes worm-eaten. Very numerous original restorations (for instance, on f. 1r). Several passages of the text have been retraced , sometimes on the paper restorations (see, for instance, folio 55 verso). The text is sometimes faded (see, for instance, folio 64 recto).

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 60 akṣaras per line.

stringHole.stringHole:
Two string holes, each approximately in in the middle of a column-like blank space.
2.3 11.4

layout.p: Only on some folios, a pair of double marginal frame lines at both sides of both folio numbers and string holes. Some puṣpikās are finely drawn in a decorative shape.

handNote.desc: First hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) script in black ink (main text).
Second hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) script in black ink (retraced text).
Third hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) script in black ink (corrections).

decoNote.desc:
The beginnings of the various dhāraṇis are decorated with polichrome miniatures, varying in width between approx. 5 and 5.5 cm, drawn in the centre of the page and protected by a layer of thin paper pasted to the recto of the respective folio:
On f. 1v, representation of the goddess Sāhasrapramardanī.
On f. 39v, representation of the goddess Māyūrī.
On f. 94v, representation of the goddess Śītavatī.
On f. 98v, representation the goddess Pratisarā.
On f. 127v, representation of the goddess Mantrānusāraṇī.

list.item: On the recto of the flyleaf, an invocation in a sort of ornamental characters (imitating the Kuṭila style): oṃ namo vāgīśvarāya ||

bindingDesc.p: On the outer side of the back cover, traces of materials smeared on the manuscript during worship rites.

decoNote.desc:
Both the inner covers bear polichrome miniatures.
On the inner side of the front cover, representations of three Buddhas, each attended by two smaller figures.
On the inner side of the back cover, representations of three Buddhas, each attended by two smaller figures.

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright on behalf of the Cambridge University Library in 1876.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
